posts.title: Week 1 of Improving Deep Neural Networks
posts.markdown:
This is my series on the 4-week course called (breathes in) [Improving Deep Neural Networks: Hyperparameter tuning, Regularization and Optimization](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/home/welcome).

# Setting up your Machine Learning Application

## Train / Dev / Test sets

[Video #1](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/cxG1s/train-dev-test-sets) says choosing the right values for hyperparameters are hard, so just start and iterate. Intuitions doesn't always transfer across applications (e.g. from image recog to speech transcript).

Setting up your data sets well will help with quicker iterations.

Hold-out / cross-validation set is aka dev set.

Dev set just needs to be big enough to evaluate algo choices.

Test set gives you an unbiased estimate of algo performance, but you might not always need one.

## Bias / Variance

[Video #2](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/ZhclI/bias-variance) says that in the deep learning era there's less of the so-called "bias-variance trade-off".

![bias and variance](/content/images/2017/11/bias-and-variance.png)

Some notes from course 3 in the specialisation apply here.

![having both problems](/content/images/2017/11/high-bias-and-high-variance.png)

## Basic Recipe for Machine Learning

[Video #3](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/ZBkx4/basic-recipe-for-machine-learning) talks about the basic recipe for the high bias/high variance issue.

![recipe](/content/images/2017/11/recipe.png)

Training a bigger network almost never hurts variance, as long as you regularise properly.

Also, in deep learning you don't have the bias/variance "trade-off".

# Regularizing your neural network

## Regularization

[Video #4](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/Srsrc/regularization) says regularisation is the first thing to try when you're overfitting or have high variance, because more data might not always be available.

### L2 in logistic regression

You add to your cost function the *regularisation parameter* lambda:

`λ/2m ||w||^2` where the norm of w squared is just a squared Euclidian norm (or L2 norm), also written `W.T * W`. This is called **L2 regularisation**.

You could add a similar parameter for *b*.

There's also L1 reg, and it's "sparse" so could compress your model, but in practice L2 is used more often as L1 helps only a bit.

λ is another hyperparameter that you have to tune.

![L2 reg](/content/images/2017/11/l2-reg.png)

### L2 in a neural network

For cost, same as before, but summing over the weight norms. It's called the "Frobenius norm" of a matrix.

For `dw`, you're adding `λ/m * W` to `dw`, and in gradient descent this is called *weight decay*.

![L2 reg in NN](/content/images/2017/11/l2-reg-nn.png)

### Summary 

![summary of L2](/content/images/2017/11/summary-of-L2.png)

### What is L2-regularization actually doing?

L2-regularization relies on the assumption that a model with small weights is simpler than a model with large weights. Thus, by penalizing the square values of the weights in the cost function you drive all the weights to smaller values (weight decay). It becomes too costly for the cost to have large weights! This leads to a smoother model in which the output changes more slowly as the input changes.

## Why regularization reduces overfitting?

[Video #5](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/T6OJj/why-regularization-reduces-overfitting) explains the intuition for why L2 reduces overfitting.

### Intuition 1

In this diagram, making λ high will make the weights go to zero, which means your network starts looking like a logistic regression unit which looks more like the high bias fit on the left, so there'll be an intermediate value for λ which gives you the "just right" fit in the middle.

![just right](/content/images/2017/11/just-right.png)

Actually, it doesn't really zero-out a lot of weight, but their effects are just softened.

### Intuition 2

Large λ means small W which means a small Z, so it takes on a small range of values (the linear bit in tanh, if your activation is tanh) so you end up with a linear network, which is something straighter than the overfit squiggly line on the right in the image above.

![L2 intuition 2](/content/images/2017/11/l2-intuition-2.png)

Debugging L2 could involve plotting the cost (against iterations) with and without L2, and verifying that the old cost doesn't decrease monotonically.

![debugging L2](/content/images/2017/11/debugging-L2.png)


## Dropout Regularization

[Video #6](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/eM33A/dropout-regularization) starts with an illustration: you disable nodes randomly to end up with a diminished network for every iteration over all samples (don't randomly change per sample!).

![dropout-to-diminish](/content/images/2017/11/dropout.png)

The recommended way to implement dropout is "inverted dropout": keep `keep_prob` percentage of weights, but bump the activation back up by dividing by `keep_prob` and it ensures that the expected value of *a* remains the same:

![inverted](/content/images/2017/11/inverted.png)

## Understanding Dropout

[Video #7](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/YaGbR/understanding-dropout) says dropout gives you a smaller network, and that has a regularising effect.

Intuition: you can't rely on any one feature, so you have to spread out the weights.

Dropout has a similar effect to L2 reg in the sense that when a weight is disabled, it has the effect of spreading out and in effect shrinking the squared norm of the weights.

You can also vary `keep_prob` by layer (although this increases the hyperparam space). `keep_prob` of 1 also means that nothing is dropping out; you're keeping everything.

The downside of dropout is that the cost function J now isn't very well defined because on every iteration you're randomly killing off nodes. You lose the plot debugging discussed previously. You can plot first with `keep_prob=1` and ensure it decreases monotonically, and only then introduce dropout and ensure you haven't introduced bugs.

![why-dropout-works](/content/images/2017/11/why-dropout-works.png)

### Remember this about dropout

- A **common mistake** when using dropout is to use it both in training and testing. You should use dropout (randomly eliminate nodes) only in training.
- Deep learning frameworks like [tensorflow](https://www.tensorflow.org/api_docs/python/tf/nn/dropout), [PaddlePaddle](http://doc.paddlepaddle.org/release_doc/0.9.0/doc/ui/api/trainer_config_helpers/attrs.html), [keras](https://keras.io/layers/core/#dropout) or [caffe](http://caffe.berkeleyvision.org/tutorial/layers/dropout.html) which we'll learn about in due course.
- Dropout is a regularization technique.
You only use dropout during training. -
- Don't use dropout (randomly eliminate nodes) during test time.
- Apply dropout both during forward and backward propagation.
- During training time, divide each dropout layer by keep_prob to keep the same expected value for the activations. For example, if keep_prob is 0.5, then we will on average shut down half the nodes, so the output will be scaled by 0.5 since only the remaining half are contributing to the solution. Dividing by 0.5 is equivalent to multiplying by 2. Hence, the output now has the same expected value. You can check that this works even when keep_prob is other values than 0.5.

Note that regularization hurts training set performance! This is because it limits the ability of the network to overfit to the training set. But since it ultimately gives better test accuracy, it is helping your system.

## Other regularization methods

[Video #8](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/Pa53F/other-regularization-methods) discusses a few more techniques.

### Data augmentation

E.g. flip images horizontally, random crops, random zooms, distortions, transformations. It's an inexpensive way to get more data, regularise, and reduce overfitting.

### Early stopping

![early stopping](/content/images/2017/11/early-stopping.png)


...but it's not orthogonal, in the sense that you're changing two things:

- reducing the cost
- not overfitting

Best just to use L2 and not stop.

# Setting up your optimization problem

## Normalizing inputs

[Video #9](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/lXv6U/normalizing-inputs)


Step 1: Subtract (or zero-out) the mean.
Step 2: normalise the variances

Use the same *mu* and *sigma squared* in the test set.

![normalise](/content/images/2017/11/normalise.png)

Why do we normalise? It will speed up gradient descent.

The illustration below doesn't apply to high-dimensional weights, but it's a good intuition in 2D.

![why normalise](/content/images/2017/11/why-normalise.png)

This type of normalisation doesn't hurt, so we do it anyway.

## Vanishing / Exploding gradients

[Video #10](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/C9iQO/vanishing-exploding-gradients) says that "exploding gradients" are when they get very big or very small, and this makes training difficult. This is alleviated by careful weight random initialisation.

![vanishing and exploding gradients](/content/images/2017/11/vanishing-and-exploding-gradients.png)

The amount of layers *L*, when large, has this effect on your gradients if *W*

- is slightly smaller (than one, or) than the identity matrix (e.g. 0.9), then your gradients vanish
- is slightly larger than the identity matrix, then your gradients (or activations) can explode

## Weight Initialization for Deep Networks

[Video #11](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/RwqYe/weight-initialization-for-deep-networks) talks about weight initialisation.

### Single neuron example

When using ReLU, one reasonable thing to do is set the variance of *Wi* to be equal to 2 over n, where n is the number of input features into the neuron (this is "He" initialisation). For tanh there's Xavier initialisation, and then there's another one invented by Bengio.

![single neuron example](/content/images/2017/11/single-neuron-example.png)

The variance parameter becomes another hyperparameter.

## Numerical approximation of gradients

[Video #12](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/XzSSa/numerical-approximation-of-gradients) says when you implement back propagation you'll find that there's a test called *gradient checking* that can really help you make sure that your implementation of back prop is correct.

It takes a "2 sided difference" of the gradient, which turns out to be more accurate:

![2-sided](/content/images/2017/11/2-sided.png)

The math showing the 1-sided difference being less accurate (0.01 as opposed to 0.0001 for 2-sided)

![2 sided math](/content/images/2017/11/2-sided-math.png)

We'll use this to do gradient checking in the next section.

## Gradient checking

[Video #13](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/htA0l/gradient-checking) says to concatenate W1, b1, ... WL, bL into a vector theta. Do the same for dW1, db1, ..., dWL, dbL into a vector d-theta. They will have the same size.

Now check if is d-theta the gradient of the cost function J of theta.

![gradient check](/content/images/2017/11/gradient-check.png)

For each component of theta *i* compute d-theta-approx-i with the two-sided difference. That's J of theta, theta-1, theta-2, up to theta-i. And we're going to nudge theta-i and add/minus epsilon to it. Just nudge theta i by epsilon, and keep everything else the same.

The video then shows the values for epsilon in the check where you should start worrying about bugs, i.e. if d-theta is very far away from d-approx-i.

![grad check](/content/images/2017/11/grad-check.png)

### Summary

![another gradient checking summary](/content/images/2017/11/another-gradient-checking-summary.png)

## Gradient Checking Implementation Notes

[Video #14](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/6igIc/gradient-checking-implementation-notes) notes some things when implementing gradient checking.

![when implementing gradient checking](/content/images/2017/11/when-implementing-gradient-checking.png)

### Things to note


- Gradient Checking is slow! Approximating the gradient with  `∂J∂θ≈J(θ+ε)−J(θ−ε)2ε∂J∂θ ≈ J(θ+ε)−J(θ−ε)2ε`  is computationally costly. For this reason, we don't run gradient checking at every iteration during training. Just a few times to check if the gradient is correct.
- Gradient Checking, at least as we've presented it, doesn't work with dropout. You would usually run the gradient check algorithm without dropout to make sure your backprop is correct, then add dropout.

# Heroes of Deep Learning

[Interview](https://www.coursera.org/learn/deep-neural-network/lecture/bqUgf/yoshua-bengio-interview) with [Yoshua Bengio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yoshua_Bengio)
posts.html:
This is my series on the 4-week course called (breathes in) Improving Deep Neural Networks: Hyperparameter tuning, Regularization and Optimization.

Setting up your Machine Learning Application

Train / Dev / Test sets

Video #1 says choosing the right values for hyperparameters are hard, so just start and iterate. Intuitions doesn't always transfer across applications (e.g. from image recog to speech transcript).

Setting up your data sets well will help with quicker iterations.

Hold-out / cross-validation set is aka dev set.

Dev set just needs to be big enough to evaluate algo choices.

Test set gives you an unbiased estimate of algo performance, but you might not always need one.

Bias / Variance

Video #2 says that in the deep learning era there's less of the so-called "bias-variance trade-off".

Some notes from course 3 in the specialisation apply here.

Basic Recipe for Machine Learning

Video #3 talks about the basic recipe for the high bias/high variance issue.

Training a bigger network almost never hurts variance, as long as you regularise properly.

Also, in deep learning you don't have the bias/variance "trade-off".

Regularizing your neural network

Regularization

Video #4 says regularisation is the first thing to try when you're overfitting or have high variance, because more data might not always be available.

L2 in logistic regression

You add to your cost function the regularisation parameter lambda:

λ/2m ||w||^2 where the norm of w squared is just a squared Euclidian norm (or L2 norm), also written W.T * W. This is called L2 regularisation.

You could add a similar parameter for b.

There's also L1 reg, and it's "sparse" so could compress your model, but in practice L2 is used more often as L1 helps only a bit.

λ is another hyperparameter that you have to tune.

L2 in a neural network

For cost, same as before, but summing over the weight norms. It's called the "Frobenius norm" of a matrix.

For dw, you're adding λ/m * W to dw, and in gradient descent this is called weight decay.

Summary

What is L2-regularization actually doing?

L2-regularization relies on the assumption that a model with small weights is simpler than a model with large weights. Thus, by penalizing the square values of the weights in the cost function you drive all the weights to smaller values (weight decay). It becomes too costly for the cost to have large weights! This leads to a smoother model in which the output changes more slowly as the input changes.

Why regularization reduces overfitting?

Video #5 explains the intuition for why L2 reduces overfitting.

Intuition 1

In this diagram, making λ high will make the weights go to zero, which means your network starts looking like a logistic regression unit which looks more like the high bias fit on the left, so there'll be an intermediate value for λ which gives you the "just right" fit in the middle.

Actually, it doesn't really zero-out a lot of weight, but their effects are just softened.

Intuition 2

Large λ means small W which means a small Z, so it takes on a small range of values (the linear bit in tanh, if your activation is tanh) so you end up with a linear network, which is something straighter than the overfit squiggly line on the right in the image above.

Debugging L2 could involve plotting the cost (against iterations) with and without L2, and verifying that the old cost doesn't decrease monotonically.

Dropout Regularization

Video #6 starts with an illustration: you disable nodes randomly to end up with a diminished network for every iteration over all samples (don't randomly change per sample!).

The recommended way to implement dropout is "inverted dropout": keep keep_prob percentage of weights, but bump the activation back up by dividing by keep_prob and it ensures that the expected value of a remains the same:

Understanding Dropout

Video #7 says dropout gives you a smaller network, and that has a regularising effect.

Intuition: you can't rely on any one feature, so you have to spread out the weights.

Dropout has a similar effect to L2 reg in the sense that when a weight is disabled, it has the effect of spreading out and in effect shrinking the squared norm of the weights.

You can also vary keep_prob by layer (although this increases the hyperparam space). keep_prob of 1 also means that nothing is dropping out; you're keeping everything.

The downside of dropout is that the cost function J now isn't very well defined because on every iteration you're randomly killing off nodes. You lose the plot debugging discussed previously. You can plot first with keep_prob=1 and ensure it decreases monotonically, and only then introduce dropout and ensure you haven't introduced bugs.

Remember this about dropout

  • A common mistake when using dropout is to use it both in training and testing. You should use dropout (randomly eliminate nodes) only in training.
  • Deep learning frameworks like tensorflow, PaddlePaddle, keras or caffe which we'll learn about in due course.
  • Dropout is a regularization technique. You only use dropout during training. -
  • Don't use dropout (randomly eliminate nodes) during test time.
  • Apply dropout both during forward and backward propagation.
  • During training time, divide each dropout layer by keepprob to keep the same expected value for the activations. For example, if keepprob is 0.5, then we will on average shut down half the nodes, so the output will be scaled by 0.5 since only the remaining half are contributing to the solution. Dividing by 0.5 is equivalent to multiplying by 2. Hence, the output now has the same expected value. You can check that this works even when keep_prob is other values than 0.5.

Note that regularization hurts training set performance! This is because it limits the ability of the network to overfit to the training set. But since it ultimately gives better test accuracy, it is helping your system.

Other regularization methods

Video #8 discusses a few more techniques.

Data augmentation

E.g. flip images horizontally, random crops, random zooms, distortions, transformations. It's an inexpensive way to get more data, regularise, and reduce overfitting.

Early stopping

...but it's not orthogonal, in the sense that you're changing two things:

  • reducing the cost
  • not overfitting

Best just to use L2 and not stop.

Setting up your optimization problem

Normalizing inputs

Video #9

Step 1: Subtract (or zero-out) the mean.
Step 2: normalise the variances

Use the same mu and sigma squared in the test set.

Why do we normalise? It will speed up gradient descent.

The illustration below doesn't apply to high-dimensional weights, but it's a good intuition in 2D.

This type of normalisation doesn't hurt, so we do it anyway.

Vanishing / Exploding gradients

Video #10 says that "exploding gradients" are when they get very big or very small, and this makes training difficult. This is alleviated by careful weight random initialisation.

The amount of layers L, when large, has this effect on your gradients if W

  • is slightly smaller (than one, or) than the identity matrix (e.g. 0.9), then your gradients vanish
  • is slightly larger than the identity matrix, then your gradients (or activations) can explode

Weight Initialization for Deep Networks

Video #11 talks about weight initialisation.

Single neuron example

When using ReLU, one reasonable thing to do is set the variance of Wi to be equal to 2 over n, where n is the number of input features into the neuron (this is "He" initialisation). For tanh there's Xavier initialisation, and then there's another one invented by Bengio.

The variance parameter becomes another hyperparameter.

Numerical approximation of gradients

Video #12 says when you implement back propagation you'll find that there's a test called gradient checking that can really help you make sure that your implementation of back prop is correct.

It takes a "2 sided difference" of the gradient, which turns out to be more accurate:

The math showing the 1-sided difference being less accurate (0.01 as opposed to 0.0001 for 2-sided)

We'll use this to do gradient checking in the next section.

Gradient checking

Video #13 says to concatenate W1, b1, ... WL, bL into a vector theta. Do the same for dW1, db1, ..., dWL, dbL into a vector d-theta. They will have the same size.

Now check if is d-theta the gradient of the cost function J of theta.

For each component of theta i compute d-theta-approx-i with the two-sided difference. That's J of theta, theta-1, theta-2, up to theta-i. And we're going to nudge theta-i and add/minus epsilon to it. Just nudge theta i by epsilon, and keep everything else the same.

The video then shows the values for epsilon in the check where you should start worrying about bugs, i.e. if d-theta is very far away from d-approx-i.

Summary

Gradient Checking Implementation Notes

Video #14 notes some things when implementing gradient checking.

Things to note

  • Gradient Checking is slow! Approximating the gradient with ∂J∂θ≈J(θ+ε)−J(θ−ε)2ε∂J∂θ ≈ J(θ+ε)−J(θ−ε)2ε is computationally costly. For this reason, we don't run gradient checking at every iteration during training. Just a few times to check if the gradient is correct.
  • Gradient Checking, at least as we've presented it, doesn't work with dropout. You would usually run the gradient check algorithm without dropout to make sure your backprop is correct, then add dropout.

Heroes of Deep Learning

Interview with Yoshua Bengio
